Class ChatProtocol

  • java.lang.Object
    • ChatProtocol

  • public final class ChatProtocol
extends java.lang.Object
    ChatProtocol constants.

    A protocol message is constructed as follows:

    • A header, consisting of
      • (byte) protocol version number
      • (byte) operation code
      • (int) payload length, not including this field, the version field, or the opcode
    • optionally, additional payload, specified for each opcode

    If the additional payload includes a String, it will be encoded as follows:

    • (byte[]) String encoded in the UTF-8 character set

    Because there is no "start session" command in the protocol that will establish a connection to the server, we always send the protocol version number. Note that since there is no login operation, the server is expected to accept any socket connection from any client.

    The protocol version will be checked by the server to ensure that the client and server are using the same protocol or versions of the protocol that are compatible. If the server determines that the protocol version used by the client and the protocol version or versions required by the server are not compatible, the server will disconnect the client. In cases where the protocols being used are not compatible, no other communication between the client and the server is guaranteed to be understood.

    We follow the Java language definitions of the basic data types. In particular, a byte is defined as 8 bits, and an int is defined as 4 bytes (32 bits). String representations will vary from environment to environment, which is why we define UTF-8 as the transfer encoding for strings. Behavior not specified in this document is left as an implementation decision for the particular client and server.

        Constant Field Values

      • CREATE_ACCOUNT_REQUEST

        public static final byte CREATE_ACCOUNT_REQUEST
        Account creation request from a client to a server. This message should only be sent to a server; if received by a client it should be ignored.
        Opcode: 0x10
        Payload:
        • (String) account_name

        The account_name is the name of the account the client wishes to create. After the server processes the creation request, the server sends one of the following acknowledgments to the client:

        • CREATE_ACCOUNT_SUCCESS, if account creation succeeds.
        • CREATE_ACCOUNT_FAILURE, if account creation fails.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • CREATE_ACCOUNT_SUCCESS

        public static final byte CREATE_ACCOUNT_SUCCESS
        Account creation success. Server response to a client's CREATE_ACCOUNT_REQUEST.
        Opcode: 0x11
        Payload:
        • (String) account_name
        The account_name is the name of the account the server just created.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • CREATE_ACCOUNT_FAILURE

        public static final byte CREATE_ACCOUNT_FAILURE
        Account creation failure. Server response to a client's CREATE_ACCOUNT_REQUEST.
        Opcode: 0x12
        Payload:
        • (String) reason
        This message indicates that the server rejects the CREATE_ACCOUNT_REQUEST for some reason, for example:
        • invalid desired account name
        • unavailable desired account name
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • LOGIN_REQUEST

        public static final byte LOGIN_REQUEST
        Login request from a client to a server. This message should only be sent to a server; if received by a client it should be ignored.
        Opcode: 0x13
        Payload:
        • (String) account_name

        The account_name is the name of the account the client wishes to login to. After the server processes the login request, the server sends one of the following acknowledgments to the client:

        • LOGIN_SUCCESS, if login succeeds.
        • LOGIN_FAILURE, if login fails.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • LOGIN_SUCCESS

        public static final byte LOGIN_SUCCESS
        Login success. Server response to a client's LOGIN_REQUEST.
        Opcode: 0x14
        Payload:
        • (String) account_name
        • (boolean) unreadMessages
        The account_name is the name of the account the client has logged into. The unreadMessages passes along to the client whether the client has unread messages in the inbox.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • LOGIN_FAILURE

        public static final byte LOGIN_FAILURE
        Login failure. Server response to a client's LOGIN_REQUEST.
        Opcode: 0x15
        Payload:
        • (String) reason
        This message indicates that the server rejects the LOGIN_REQUEST for some reason, for example:
        • invalid account name
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DELETE_ACCOUNT_REQUEST

        public static final byte DELETE_ACCOUNT_REQUEST
        Account destruction request from a client to a server. This message should only be sent to a server; if received by a client it should be ignored.
        Opcode: 0x20
        Payload:
        • (String) account_name

        The account_name is the name of the account to be deleted. After the server processes the deletion request, the server sends one of the following acknowledgments to the client:

        • DELETE_ACCOUNT_SUCCESS, if account deletion succeeds.
        • DELETE_ACCOUNT_FAILURE, if account deletion fails.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

        Opcode: 0x21
        Payload: None.

        This message indicates that the server rejects the DELETE_ACCOUNT_REQUEST for some reason, for example:

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • LIST_ALL_ACCOUNTS_REQUEST

        public static final byte LIST_ALL_ACCOUNTS_REQUEST
        List all accounts request from a client to a server. Requests a list of all accounts, or a subset of accounts by text wildcard. The server should then begin to send all account names, one per protocol message, to the client. This message should only be sent to a server; if received by a client it should be ignored.
        Opcode: 0x30
        Payload:
        • (String) regular_expression

        The regular_expression is a Java regular expression used to pattern match account names. Can be '.*' to obtain all accounts currently saved. After the server processes the list all accounts request, the server sends one of the following acknowledgments to the client:

        • LIST_ALL_ACCOUNTS_SUCCESS, if list all accounts request succeeds.
        • LIST_ALL_ACCOUNTS_FAILURE, if list all accounts request fails.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • LIST_ALL_ACCOUNTS_SUCCESS

        public static final byte LIST_ALL_ACCOUNTS_SUCCESS
        List all accounts success. Server response to a client's LIST_ALL_ACCOUNTS_REQUEST.
        Opcode: 0x31
        Payload: None.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • LIST_ALL_ACCOUNTS_FAILURE

        public static final byte LIST_ALL_ACCOUNTS_FAILURE
        List all accounts failure. Server response to a client's LIST_ALL_ACCOUNTS_REQUEST.
        Opcode: 0x32
        Payload:
        • (String) reason
        This message indicates that the server rejects the LIST_ALL_ACCOUNTS_REQUEST for some reason, for example:
        • invalid regular expression.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • SEND_MESSAGE_REQUEST

        public static final byte SEND_MESSAGE_REQUEST
        Send message request from a client to a server. Requests a message String to be sent to a specific user. This message should only be sent to a server; if received by a client it should be ignored.
        Opcode: 0x40
        Payload:
        • (String) sender_name
        • (String) receiver_name
        • (String) message

        The receiver_name is the name of the account receiving the message message. The (String) sender_name is the account sending the message. After the server processes the send message request, the server sends one of the following acknowledgments to the client:

        • SEND_MESSAGE_SUCCESS, if send message request succeeds.
        • SEND_MESSAGE_FAILURE, if send message request fails.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • SEND_MESSAGE_SUCCESS

        public static final byte SEND_MESSAGE_SUCCESS
        Send message success. Server response to a client's SEND_MESSAGE_REQUEST.
        Opcode: 0x41
        Payload: None.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • SEND_MESSAGE_FAILURE

        public static final byte SEND_MESSAGE_FAILURE
        Send message failure. Server response to a client's SEND_MESSAGE_REQUEST.
        Opcode: 0x42
        Payload:
        • (String) reason
        This message indicates that the server rejects the SEND_MESSAGE_REQUEST for some reason, for example:
        • invalid receiver account name
        • invalid message
        • message exceeds maximum length
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • PULL_ALL_MESSAGES_REQUEST

        public static final byte PULL_ALL_MESSAGES_REQUEST
        Pull all messages request from a client to a server. Requests all messages under the client's account, to be displayed to the client. The server should send all messages to the client. This message should only be sent to a server; if received by a client it should be ignored.
        Opcode: 0x50
        Payload: None.

        After the server processes the pull all messages request, the server sends one of the following acknowledgments to the client:

        • PULL_ALL_MESSAGES_SUCCESS, if pull all messages request succeeds.
        • PULL_ALL_MESSAGES_FAILURE, if pull all messages request fails.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • PULL_ALL_MESSAGES_SUCCESS

        public static final byte PULL_ALL_MESSAGES_SUCCESS
        Pull all messages success. Server response to a client's PULL_ALL_MESSAGES_REQUEST.
        Opcode: 0x51
        Payload: None.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • PUSH_MESSAGE_NOTIFICATION

        public static final byte PUSH_MESSAGE_NOTIFICATION
        Server pushes notification that client has received a message PUSH_MESSAGE_NOTIFICATION.
        Opcode: 0x53
        No payload.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • END_SESSION_REQUEST

        public static final byte END_SESSION_REQUEST
        Request from a client to a server to disconnect and log out. This message should only be sent to a server; if received by a client it should be ignored.
        Opcode: 0x60
        Payload: None.

        This operation cannot fail, as it simply notifies the server of the client's intent to log out. After the server processes the disconnect request, the server sends END_SESSION_SUCCESS to the client.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • END_SESSION_SUCCESS

        public static final byte END_SESSION_SUCCESS
        End session success. Server response to a client's END_SESSION_REQUEST.
        Opcode: 0x61
        Payload: None.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • HEARTBEAT

        public static final byte HEARTBEAT
        Heartbeat opcode to check if client is connected.
        Opcode: 0x62
        Payload: None.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • UNKNOWN_OPCODE

        public static final byte UNKNOWN_OPCODE
        Message from the server to the client indicating that a message with an unknown opcode has been received. On the second receipt of an unknown opcode, the server will disconnect the client, after sending an END_SESSION_SUCCESS message. Opcode: Ox70
        Payload: None.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values
